user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
```c
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only controlling expression in the function is the do-while condition 'while (!got_next)'. That controlling expression and the initializer of the controlling flag (got_next = false) are the pieces that can make the loop controlling expression invariant and therefore need investigation. Other conditional expressions do not need investigation for Rule 14.3: the 'if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)' test is dependent on the incremented iter->token.obj_idx so it is not invariant; the 'if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(...))' test depends on the function pointer, its argument and the record returned by OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, so it is not invariant; the macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET ultimately indexes using token->obj_idx, which is modified in the loop; assignments such as iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED and iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id are not controlling expressions. Therefore those other fragments do not meet the criteria for Rule 14.3 investigation.
